A 7 -day-old infant girl is brought into the emergency department unconscious. Her parents accompany her and report a history of an uneventful pregnancy and delivery at 39 weeks' gestational age, with no unusual postnatal events, and discharge on day of life 2. The parents report that the infant's behavior was normal during the first 3 days at home, but for the past 2 days she has not wanted to feed as much. They were not terribly concerned until about an hour before admission when she became difficult and then impossible to awaken. Emergency department personnel report that they already have plans to evaluate the infant for a cardiac lesion and infectious disease. What are the most important immediate steps in evaluation and treatment of this critically ill infant?

options.label: A
options.text: Obtain an electrocardiogram (ECG) to look for occult arrhythmia.

options.label: B
options.text: Measure glucose, lactic acid, and ammonia, and start IV fluids with at least 10 % dextrose concentration

options.label: C
options.text: Start the infant on ampicillin and gentamicin for presumed sepsis.

options.label: D
options.text: Await the results of an echocardiogram before making further management decisions.

options.label: E
options.text: Obtain plasma amino acids and urine organic acids to look for metabolic disease.

questions.correct_answer: B. Measure glucose, lactic acid, and ammonia, and start IV fluids with at least 10 % dextrose concentration

questions.text: Maple syrup urine disease is a disorder of branched-chain amino acids. Which of the following amino acids is not considered a branched-chain amino acid that would be elevated in a patient with maple syrup urine disease?

A 13-year-old postmenarchal girl comes to the clinic with concerns of early morning clumsiness after several episodes of breaking dishes and glasses at breakfast. She describes an uncontrollable brief jerk of her shoulders and arms that causes them to fling out, resulting in the broken dishes. On further questioning, she admits to having had a few episodes where she woke up having wet the bed at night and with blood in her mouth from biting his tongue. Her exam is normal. You suspect seizures and order an MRI, which is normal, and an EEG, which shows a 4- to 6-Hz generalized polyspike-and-wave pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?

During another busy day in clinic, a 5-month-old boy is referred to you for evaluation of atypical movements. The infant was born at term and had been healthy with normal development. A few weeks ago, he started having attacks during which his body crunches up repeatedly then stops. The dusters frequently occur right after he wakes up. The mother shows you a video on her phone. During the episode, the infant's head thrusts forward while his entire body repeatedly flexes together and then extends. What is the most likely cause of these events?
2 Images: Patient with lung cancer. Image 1 shows a right hilar mass. What complication has occurred at the time of image 2 which was acquired 4 months after image 1?
Alcoholic found unconscious. What does the image show?
An 80-year-old woman known for a chronic bone disorder with markedly elevated serum alkaline phosphatase. What is the most likely chronic bone disease shown on her lateral skull radiograph?
40 year old male patient with mucopurulent cough underwent CT examination, what is the most likely diagnosis?
30 year old with BMI 18 with progressive difficulty in swallowing in both solids and liquids for 8 months. Barium swallow is shown to you. What other investigation should be done in this patient?
